creditline: On loan from the collection of Jack and Connie Wallinga
description: figure stands on small round base; fabric is wrapped from waist to feet; a round barrel shapped form extends from the mid-section with inset mirror; slightly gapping mouth with fine facial features and porcelain eyes; rounded tall headdress with spiked forms set in earth material covers headdress; square metal base
medium: Wood, glass, porcelain, metal, cloth, plant fiber, undermined materials
text: This dynamically carved, small nkisi would have been used as a power figure for healing and protection in a family compound. It is charged with sacred and efficacious substances, considered to act like "medicine"-one of the meanings of the word nkisi. These substances are hidden in the crown of the head, the collar around the neck, the box on the abdomen, and the pack between the legs. The mirrors on the head and the abdomen suggest the surface of water that separates the world of the living and that of the spirits; they allow the nkisi to "see" what is hidden and ward off evil forces.
title: Power figure
